abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Health Systems
            Reconstruction Project for Ethiopia were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory; risk to development
            outcome was moderate; Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory and borrower performance was also moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned includes: the capacity of
            implementers should be carefully considered in the project
            design, and implementation, and supported by adequate Bank
            Budget (BB). An emergency project needs to be prepared
            quickly, but this should not deflect attention from having a
            well-designed project, with a minimum of basic
            pre-requisites for a meaningful purpose, suitable design,
            realistic approach, and simplicity to generate an effective
            rapid response. Innovations in design-particularly as they
            related to capacity constraints-should be encouraged in
            fragile, post-conflict countries.
